ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Differential equations!

Greater familiarity with differential equations and methods of solving them. While we began with the basics of first order differential equations, we mostly focused on various second order ODEs and PDEs. The methods we learned covered homogenous and non-homogenous equations with constant coefficients, series solutions, Euler equations, Laplace transforms, and PDEs with the method of separation of variables.
Differential equations
I definitely learned the mathematical applications of a lot of daily phenomena
I learned a lot about solving various ordinary and partial differential equations, and I also learned about some interesting applications of differential applications in engineering.
How to solve differential equations
techniques of solving differential equations
Learned basic techniques of solving various differential equations
Various techniques for solving differential equations
Characteristic equations, series, Laplace transform, Fourier series, heat/wave equation, Dirichlet problem
I learned how to solve many differential equations with a great variety of applications.

I learned a lot in this course: how to solve ordinary differential equations with various formulas, brushed up on power series and its use in solving differential equations, setting up differential equations in real-life problems, solving partial differential equations with examples like heat in a metal rod and waves, convolution integrals, Fourier series, Laplace transforms, Sturm-Liouville theory.
Solving homogeneous and nonhomogeneous differential equations, learning about different types of differential equations, famous differential equations and the people behind them
i learned how to evaluate various differential equations and solve for different types of solutions based in the given problem.

I furthered my mathematics skills specifically learning the various methods to solve differential equations. I also learned about the mathematicians and scholars who developed the theories in this course.
Gained a deeper understanding of how to solve partial and ordinary differential equations and their different applications. Did not gain much insight into theory (which was FINE by me!).

I learned a lot about differential equations.  I now feel a lot more comfortable with the applications of these techniques and discerning when it is appropriate to use each technique depending on the context.
I learned how to use various techniques solve differential equations.
Through this course, I learned methods for solving basic differential equations. I gained skills in understanding solutions to these equations.
I learned how to solve elementary initial value and boundary value differential equation problems with methods like the Laplace Tranform method and separation of variables.
I learned more about methods of calculation that are connected to Physics and Engineering.
The knowledge to solve differential equations
I was able to gain an understanding of various units of differential equations.
Really helpful in applications that will be used in engineering.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths are the prof, teaching style, and exam setup. Weaknesses would be the amount of pset and info we were sometimes not taught that showed up on psets.

Strengths: The greatest strength of this course was Professor Smooke--he was awesome.  This class is inherently a bit repetitive in the sense that you spend an entire semester only solving differential equations, but Prof. Smooke made the best of it. The pre-recorded lectures were helpful and a good way of getting the material to sink in. Class was basically a repeat of the recordings, but it was completely optional and he was always willing to answer questions in class itself.  As for the material itself, it was very unsurprising--and I mean this in the best possible way. The PSETs were a bit of a stretch from lecture, and they could definitely take a while, but the book always made up for anything the lectures missed and the PSETs were really good preparation for our exams--the exams basically followed standard or on-the-easier-side PSET problems.

Weaknesses: For me, the in-class lectures could be a bit fast--I couldn't really take complete notes unless I used the prerecorded lectures or just wrote non-stop for the class. Content wise, an annoying feature was that certain concepts weren't terribly difficult to set up, but procedures like shifting multiple series or doing many rounds of integration by parts were tedious and frustrating at times.
It was not very engaging and I had a hard time learning from the lectures.

The homework assignments were all well structured to help prepare for exams and the exams reflected the homework problems quite closely.

I have no criticisms for this course, expect for the fact that perhaps better/more structured review sessions could be held?
asynchronous videos were well-done, sometimes synchronous class felt redundant

Strengths - recorded lectures
Weaknesses - lectures seemed to be a regurgitation of textbook chapters and didn't add too much
Neutral - some p-sets felt very "grindy"

Mitch is a great person, but the way he does the lectures is not the best. He reads off the slides, the slides are basically exactly the same material as the textbook, and there is no writing or solving problems real-time/on-the-spot involved. The tests were okay, but some tested concepts we could not have derived simply out of observation.

I think it was great to have the pre-recorded lectures. It helped me keep up with synchronous lecture. Professor Smooke and the TA's were great. I hope he posts the lecture slides in his other courses as well. I saw no weaknesses in this class. Tests were very fair, and preparation was very straight-forward.

Strengths: Great professor who wanted to engage with us and was interested in the topic.  Class organized very clearly and many opportunities for peer tutor/TA office hours, which were of invaluable help to me.  I liked how the professor posted recorded lecture modules to watch before going over the same concepts in class.  This way, I could take notes off of the videos and really listen during the live lectures rather than scrambling to write down everything as fast as I could.  I really hope the professor keeps these recorded videos during in-person classes.  I loved having 4 exams rather than a cumulative final.  It really made me invested in learning the material deeply rather than trying to cram for a final.  Also, I liked the bonus questions on the exams about the mathematicians we learned about.
Weaknesses: The only weakness I can really think of is the fact that we didn't know if we were going to cover some concepts until the end of the semester.  Also, having the final two exams only 1.5 weeks apart from each other could have been restructured.  The only other thing is that problem set lengths varied drastically.  This was fine for some weeks, but other weeks I wished there was more consistency.  There was about a 250% difference in length of problem sets between shortest and longest.

Strengths: It was very helpful that the course followed the textbook so closely, and I appreciated the repetition of the concepts with the recorded lecture and the live lecture.
Weaknesses: The live lectures were nearly identical to the recorded ones.  Also, just reading slides in the recorded lectures meant that there was a ton of text on the slide that I felt very rushed trying to copy down.  I would have loved to see more synthesis of the material and presenting problems through writing and working through them, rather than showing them on PowerPoint.
a lot of the homework work felt menial and was very time consuming even though the time consuming parts were not the focus of the course
The learning method needs more creativity and explanation. More examples of the different equations. Please shorten the PSETS

The strengths of the course is that the information builds upon itself such that an understanding of earlier concepts is helpful later on in the course. Also, the combination of recorded lectures and virtual lectures gave many opportunities to better learn and comprehend the information. A weakness of this course is that the concepts learned are very difficult but this is partly mitigated by the multitude of learning opportunities.

Prof. Smooke is a very straightforward professor; as long as you attend lectures/watch modules and do the PSETs, the exams are straightforward. Also, I loved that his lectures were extremely succinct and that he never really went over an hour in lectures. However, a lot of lecture material was the same as the module material, which made live lectures bland at times. I would've appreciated getting to do more practice problems as a class during lecture time, which would allow us students to be more engaged with the class and to also gain some new insights that weren't offered in the modules.

I think the course was structured so that the material was manageable and easy to understand. It was really helpful to be able to review the material as it helped me understand not only the concept, but the rationale for using it.  In addition, it was interesting to see how the concepts built on each other.  I do wish that there were some practice exams or study guides for the exams as there was often a lot of material to review. In addition,  the questions in the book often explored additional concepts, so it was hard to find questions to do that were relavent to the material learned in class.

There are a lot of resources to help students succeed in the class, but the material is tedious and the class could be done just as easily by reading the book and following the example problems. The toughness with the course lies within the tenacity of accurately writing many, many steps to solve a single differential equations problem. In addition, the problem sets in the class were extremely inconsistent in length: sometimes, it would take 1 hour to finish the problem sets; sometimes it would take 10.

The course was strong in its ability to allow for individual practice working with differential equations.
The course was weak in that it introduced solutions without reasoning and often began from much higher levels of understanding for a class given to students who have never seen certain functions and symbols that are a part of differential equation solutions.

The TAs were really helpful, and I managed to find the material quite interesting. I just wish that we would go over some of the more complex material in lecture a bit more thoroughly. The lecture slides were written quite concisely, but that also meant that there were multiple times where I felt lost and needed to go back into the textbook to clear up certain ideas.

It is a class that doesnt necessarily seem like it would spark the interest of math majors, but it is good for understanding the general topics. The only major drawback was that watching the lectures live or the recorded ones didnt make a difference. It was like watching the recorded lecture twice with added facts about the people who made the methods.
Not much guided problem practice. Had to learn how to do problems on my own for the most part. No test prep material. Lectures provided good background knowledge, TAs were very helpful.

I thought this course was strong in the sense that the pre-lecture videos along with the live lectures themselves really allowed for an understanding of the material on a weekly basis. At times though, I felt as if the homework questions were not a good representation of the material in the sense that they required an additional level of understanding that was not provided in either forms of lectures. I think that in the future, the amount of time required to finish psets should be kept in mind as towards the end of the semester, questions took longer and longer to answer within themselves. I will also say that overall, the tests were a good representation of the material learned in class as well as the homework with the exception of the last exam.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The optional lectures in advance were very helpful for both learning the material and planning out your time--one could definitely do well in the class by only using those.
The virtual lecture could be improved. I found that I liked the pre recorded lectures more and learned more from them than lecture.
Recording of the lectures was really helpful.
synchronous class could have had different content/practice problems more frequently
To be honest, I stopped attending in-person lectures as much of the content was the same as the pre-recorded lectures. I still did fine on the exams/psets just viewing those and reading the textbook.
Recorded lectures were great and Yale should always have them

The asynchronous lectures were great. You could pause them and really make sure you understood the material going into class. I personally think these lectures should remain a part of courses like this. I thought the synchronous lectures being shortened made it very easy to look forward to class and have fun weekly.
It was good that the professor consistently asked everyone to turn on their videos.  It made the class much more engaging.

I liked that we got to have both of the live and recorded lectures, since it gave me more time to process the material.  However, the PowerPoint format of the lectures made me feel like I was just rushing to copy things down rather than working through problems and concepts.  I also appreciated the large number of virtual office hours because it made it very easy to just come for a little bit if I had a small question.
the prerecorded lectures allowed me to prepare on my own time and at my own pace although I wish the in person lectures content was more focused on different content from the recording, like examples
the pre recorded lectures were short but concise, and the live zooms were a little repetitive
Classes become more enjoyable when collaborating with students, the Covid pandemic decreased engagement with peers.
I think that the combination of recorded and live lectures during COVID-19 was successful as well as addition new interesting material to the live lectures different from the recording.
I would've liked for more practice problems to be done during our live lecture, so that we could have been more engaged with the material.

The course had both virtual lectures and recorded lectures. I really enjoyed this format as I was able to complete my notes ahead of time and ask any questions I had during class.  I also really enjoyed all of the office hours offered. It was really helpful to be able to go over concepts while doing the psets.

I think that virtual office hours were extremely successful, as it allowed for more opportunities to just go to office hours for a quick question. I also like how the recorded lectures were easy to access and well organized, and it was easy to refer back to these recorded lectures.

However, due to the presence of recorded lectures, it made the live lectures seem really redundant. Professor Smooke often went into random tangents about random things, like the Swiss Franc or golf. The lectures seemed to be redundant, and I did not find them engaging or helpful.
Live lectures will probably be exactly like the recorded lectures, except there wont be posted recorded lectures. This means that nothing, COVID-wise, changed much about the course.
Virtual lectures were informative, communication was good.
Seeing the material twice was very helpful.

It was very helpful to have recorded lectures along with live lectures. I think this practice should definitely be kept for for post-pandemic academic interactions! I will say though that I didn't think that it made sense that our mics had to be kept on during exams. Especially during the last exam, this practice proved to be more distracting than at all helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah especially if it's with Smooke. He's a great professor and I'm sad I couldn't take it in person with him.
Only if it's required/you are willing to put in extra work aside from class and assignments to apply what you've worked on

If you're an engineering student, you are required to take this class, and that's the boat I fell into. But, if you are interested in bolstering your differential equation solving skills through a very practical/problem solving oriented class, I'd recommend it. The skillset you gain by the end of the class is expansive and seems like it will be very useful for pretty much anything engineering to come. It is a lot of work, but there are many office hours and the PSETs and tests are definitely manageable.
Yes, the applications of this course are very important for engineering majors.
I would recommend this course to another students who needs to take a differential equations course. The class was well structured and I felt adequately prepared for exams.
Sure, whenever possible, try to take math classes outside the math department.
yes if you need to take a diff eq class
Yes! Pace of material is quick but not unmanageable.
One of those courses that you probably know if you should take or not already - take if you need to as an engineering/STEM student, don't take otherwise

Mitch is a great person, but the way he does the lectures is not the best. He reads off the slides, the slides are basically exactly the same material as the textbook, and there is no writing or solving problems real-time/on-the-spot involved. If you want a very general introduction into differential equations, I would take it and know that you will do fine if you read the textbook/do many practice problems.

Yes I would. Professor Smooke makes the course very fun. I personally found this class to be much more engaging and interesting than Math 120. The assignments were manageable, and there were many resources to help you succeed. You can perform very well if you try hard in the class. I think it was outstanding.

I would highly recommend.  I was TERRIFIED to take this class during the spring of my sophomore year after having a terrible experience with Math 120 the fall of my first year.  Math 120 made me never want to take a math course again, but I'm very glad I took this course.  The course was challenging, but a type of challenging that you could get through with careful attention to detail, time spent in office hours, and extra time taking notes from the textbook.  (With Math 120, I felt that no matter what I did I could not get a grasp on the subject, but with this course I felt confident after spending extra time studying and doing practice problems.)  The exams were very fair and I thought the class atmosphere was great.  Not being an engineering major, the only doubt I had about this course is how I would apply it in my future studies and career.

If you have to take differential equations, yes.  This course was straightforward.  Homework followed the book/lectures, the exams were generally very fair, and I felt like I gained familiarity with a lot of difficult concepts.
absolutely! this class is required a lot of the time and would be good for stem majors to get an idea of how to solve odes

I would recommend this course to another student because the math topics learned are useful to other applications, specifically engineering, and the course set up to help students grasp the difficult concepts.

If you have to take ENAS 194, I would recommend Prof. Smooke. He doesn't try to play any tricks on his students and assignments/exams are all extremely straightforward. If you want to take this class to get a really deep, conceptual understanding, look elsewhere. A lot of the class material was application-based and plug-and-chug.

I would definitely recommend this course if you want to learn more about the applications of the math! It was really interesting to be able to do problems with context which definitely helped me understand the concepts more.

I would recommend the course only if it is required for your major. There are more interesting math classes to take, and in addition differential equations can all be solved online through computers and calculators now.
It's a nice course, but I would only really recommend taking it if you have an interest in math or need it for your major.

I would not recommend this course to others unless they are a math major or going into engineering/physics. The usefulness of the material beyond that isnt existent to my knowledge. Even for some engineering majors the material feels almost loosely connected.
Yes, because it is well taught and allows you to enter higher levels of mathematics.
To those who need to take for major, yes. Otherwise no, as it did not teach me many skills outside of math/engineering specific areas.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of recorded lectures and in-person lectures
Recorded Lecture
Videos of the lecture slides were usually posted in advance, and it was helpful to look at and take notes on those before coming to class
Records live lectures and posts modules
There were also prerecorded lectures.
recorded and in person lecture
We had live lectures but they were also recorded for our convenience.
Also had an in person lecture
asynchronous pre-lecture videos
There were also recorded lectures
Reading textbook
Recorded videos
There were also a lot of asynchronous lectures. I personally enjoyed them because you got to see the material twice and then look it over again before tests.
Live virtual lecture, with recorded lectures that we watched before coming to live lecture.  (Recorded and live went over the same topics and examples, live just had some extra information.)
recorded lectures before class
pre recorded lecture videos
The class included live virtual lectures as well as recorded lectures before class.
Live virtual lecture with pre-recorded modules that we had to view beforehand.
This course was a mix of virtual lectures and recorded lectures.
This course had recorded lectures posted every week, followed by live lectures on Mondays and Wednesdays. In my opinion, this made the course feel extremely long and redundant.
Recorded lectures, reading the textbook
pre-recorded lecture
Recorded lectures
Recorded lecture in combination with live virtual
Recorded Lecture
Live virtual lecture and pre-recorded lecture.
There were also recorded lectures that accompanied that live lectures every week.
